params.text:
• Welcoming a Foreign Visitor
  • Better Understand the Visitor
  • Time Indications

Welcoming Visitors

Develop Strategies to
Welcome Visitors

Language in Action

Welcome to this module on welcoming visitors! Here, we'll explore strategies to make a positive first impression and ensure foreign visitors feel comfortable. 

By the end, you'll be able to:

1. Greet Foreign Visitors: Learn how to greet visitors from other countries in a professional and friendly way.

  2. Understand the Visitor: Practice asking questions to understand the visitor's needs and purpose for visiting.

  3. Time Indications: Master using time expressions to effectively communicate schedules and deadlines.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is the MOST important thing to do when welcoming a visitor?
answers:
Make eye contact and smile. 

Ask them about their travel plans. 

Discuss the purpose of their visit right away.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: When shaking hands with a visitor, your handshake should be:
answers:
Gentle and firm.

Very firm and strong.

Loose and limp.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: If a visitor's English seems limited, you should:
answers:
Speak slowly and clearly, allowing extra time to respond. 

Speak even faster to get to the point. 

Ask them to repeat themselves constantly.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Please read the following text and answer the quiz questions:

Making a good first impression is important in any situation, and especially when welcoming visitors from other countries. Here are some tips to ensure a warm and professional reception:

  • Smile and make eye contact. A friendly smile shows you're happy to see them. Eye contact conveys that you're interested and attentive.

 

  • Use a professional greeting. A simple "Hello" or "Good morning" is always appropriate. You can also add their name, like "Hello, Ms. Johnson."

• Offer a handshake. A firm but gentle handshake is a common way to greet someone in business settings.

 

  • Acknowledge their origin. You can say something like "Welcome to our company!" or "We're glad you could visit us from [country]."

 

  • Be patient with communication. If English isn't their first language, speak slowly and clearly. Allow extra time for them to understand and respond.

questions:
Is there anything specific you'd like to *discuss* during your visit today? 
I see from your *email* that you're interested in Marketing. Can you tell me more about that? 
How can I *assist* you today? 
Were you hoping to meet with *someone* in particular today?
Is this your first *visit* to our office?

metadata.title: Better Understand the Visitor- Fill in the Blanks

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: How does Abigail sometimes find out why a visitor is coming to the office?
answers:
From their email when they schedule the visit. 

By looking at their ID badge

By reading their mind!

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Abigail say she might ask a visitor directly?
answers:
"Is there anything specific you'd like to discuss today?" 

"What's your favorite color?" 

"Do you need help finding the bathroom?"

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Abigail suggest if a visitor's English is not perfect?
answers:
Use simple words, speak slowly, and use pictures. 

Speak very quickly so they can understand better. 

Ask them to translate everything into another language.

params.text: Better Understand the Visitor: Conversation and Quiz
Please listen to the following conversation and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Bryan: Hi, how do you usually find out why visitors are coming to the office?

Abigail: Hi, There are a few ways! Sometimes they mention it when they schedule the visit by email.

Bryan: That's a good point. Do you ever ask them directly when they arrive?

Abigail: Yes, of course! I might say something like, "Is there anything specific you'd like to discuss during your visit today?"

Bryan: That's a great question. And what about if their English isn't perfect?

Abigail: No problem! I can use simple words and speak slowly. Sometimes I can even show them pictures on the computer to help them understand.

Bryan: That's a clever idea! Using visuals can be really helpful. Thanks!

Abigail: You're welcome!

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: A visitor arrives at your office, but you didn't receive an email about their visit beforehand. What would you do FIRST?
answers:
Greet them with a smile and ask, "How can I assist you today?" 

Ask them to wait silently until someone else becomes available. 

Tell them they must have come to the wrong place.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: A visitor speaks English, but you notice they seem to be struggling a little. What can you do to help them understand you better?
answers:
Speak slowly and clearly, using simple words. You can also use gestures to help explain.

Use more complex vocabulary and speak quickly. 

Ignore their difficulty and continue speaking as usual.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: You've confirmed a visitor's purpose for coming to the office. They are there to meet with someone specific. What should you do next?
answers:
Offer them a beverage and a brochure about your company while they wait. 

Leave them waiting in the lobby for a long time. 

Tell them the person they are meeting is unavailable and send them away.

params.text: Choose the BEST answer for each question based on what you learned about welcoming visitors.

Knowing how to talk about time clearly is essential when welcoming visitors.

Here are some helpful strategies:

• This means arriving exactly at the scheduled time.
    Example: "The meeting starts on time at 10:00 am, so please be sure to arrive a few minutes early."

• This indicates a specific duration of time.
    Example: The presentation will only take for 15 minutes.

• This means arriving at a convenient time before or around the scheduled time, not necessarily exactly at the moment.
    Example: "We can meet in time for your lunch break if that works for you.

• This means something will happen in a short period of time from now.
    Example: I will be with you in 5 minutes to answer your questions

params.textField:
The conference call starts *at 2.00 pm sharp*, so please be ready to join on time. 
We are happy to meet with you *in time* for your coffee break at 10:30 am. 
The tour of the facility will only take *for 20 minutes*, so you will still have plenty of time for your meeting afterwards. 
I will be able to print your visitor badge *in just a moment*
We can start the meeting in 5 *minutes* if that's helpful.

The flight arrives on time *at 11.15 am*, so we should head to the airport by 10:30 am.
Ms. Jones will be available to meet with you *in about an hour*. Can I offer you a beverage while you wait? 
The deadline for submitting the application is in two *weeks*, on August 1st. 
The meeting will take place for the next *hour*, so feel free to bring any questions you may have. 
We can discuss this further *over lunch*. Would 1:00 pm work for you?

params.text:
Test your instruction-following skills!
Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: When welcoming a visitor from another country, it's important to:
answers:
Make eye contact, smile, and use a professional greeting.

Ask them personal questions about their travel plans. 

Speak very quickly so they can understand you better.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: If a visitor's English seems limited, you should:
answers:
Speak slowly and clearly, using simple words. 

Get frustrated and ask them to repeat themselves constantly. 

Ignore their difficulty and continue speaking at your normal pace.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: How can you find out why a visitor is coming to the office?
answers:
You can ask them directly, "Is there anything specific you'd like to discuss today?" 

It's not polite to ask – you should just wait for them to tell you. 

Read their mind!

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: What can you do to help a visitor feel comfortable if they seem nervous?
answers:
Be patient, smile, and offer them a seat. 

Tell them they have nothing to worry about. 

Ask them a lot of questions right away.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: The meeting starts at 10:00 am. This means you should arrive:
answers:
Exactly at 10:00 am. 

Anytime before noon. 

A few minutes late – it's okay.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: I will be with you in 5 minutes. This means waiting:
answers:
For a short period of time, around 5 minutes. 

No time at all – I'm already here. 

For a very long time.
